For the record, the `--encoding` option was added to set the encoding of the _source_ file, not the resulting one (OK the doc of the task should be rewritten). But I can't see anybody wanting iso-\d+ based presentations, as utf-8 will cover everything he needs natively.

Also, `utf-8` is a correct value for html, but AFAICR `utf8` is the value used to set the character encoding for python `codecs.open` function. Here the patch could break things...

Adam and others, thoughts?

Thanks for looking at this, n1k0.

I'm far from a python native. But I am a firm believer in UTF-8. When I tested an iso-8859-1 file with the --encoding option, I noticed the html output with in fact iso-8859-1 but the meta tag for content-type pretended it was utf-8.

Also, first time I actually use github to fork and patch something. Hope I'm not causing too much trouble :)

I tested with passing no encoding option, utf8, utf-8, and iso-8859-1 with corresponding input files and it all worked as expected.

Okay interesting, if we could provide clean and transparent I/O encoding transformation, it would be great! (but in my own experience, this usually turns into a nightmare ;))

I'll investigate…

Hi, I'm the one who fixed the unicode bug with rst. I may have broken the support for non unicode sources... I agree with n1k0 that the html produced should always be utf-8 encoded. Much simpler to handle, imho.

I think I have a better solution in pull-request #24. For the record, the name of utf-8 encoding in the codecs module is `utf_8` (http://docs.python.org/library/codecs.html#standard-encodings). But other aliases as `utf8` are accepted as well.

Mmmh, why not use standard rst syntax here? I believe the standard way around this is to use a syntax like:
    .. code-block:: python

```
some code here
```

Besides, if i'm not mistaken, it's already in the [pygment repo](http://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/pygments-main/src/tip/external/rst-directive.py).

I don't personally use ReST, so a good idea would probably to leave the feature be implemented by someone who actually uses it :-)

I did it in my branch (commit olivierverdier/landslide@d04f0961d2c3cdffb15a64cc22193ff54e9cd800). I think it's cleaner to use rst directives. I use the code in the pygment repo out of the box, and used the same directive name they use, which is `sourcecode`.
I agree, this is cleaner. And both syntaxes can probably live together... :)

Are you sure that sourcecode is an official directive ? Because I use rst2pdf tools that uses the code-block directive. This directive is no more an official one. I tested the sourcecode directive and rst2pdf does not understand it. I suspect the ReST specification not to have any "block of source code" directive... Nevertheless, I can easily search/replace my code-block directives into sourcecode ones before using landslide.

I don't think that there is an official name for that directive. I just took the one from the [pygment repository](http://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/pygments-main/src/tip/external/rst-directive.py), which uses `sourcecode`.

I totally agree to change the name to `code-block` if that achieves a better consensus. (We could also have an alias, i.e., both names working the same, as is done for example [there](http://code.google.com/p/ra-blog/source/browse/trunk/BartleBlog/rst/sourcecode.py?spec=svn367&r=367))
+1 for supporting both names (plus generic cross-compatible landslide syntax)

Align directives are not parsed neither... .. image:: images/arrays.png :align: center

Is that a Restructured Text directive?

The table of contents in landslide is built from slide breaks. We are not using ReST specific commands.

The ToC generated by rendering samples/example seems to work fine.

Yes it is a restructured text directive that asks to put a TOC inside the text width depth 1 (the depth is relative to the place of the directive). The text of the TOC is generated well but the links are pointing to slides that do not exist, for example: file:///home/jf/swap/presentation.html#second-slide I have also some troubles with the TOC generated to navigate into the presentation (maybe relative to this problem ?).

If you test the example I gave above, you will see that the landslide toc (hitting "t" to make appear the toc) is not usable. I think that the ..contents breaks something somewhere because the links are #id1 and #id2 instead of #slide1 and #slide2.

I understand what you're trying to achieve, but I'm not really sure it's in the scope of Landslide — which is "just" a presentation generator, like PPT or Keynote are. Would you ever think producing a thesis using Powerpoint? ;)

But that's my point of view, others may have other opinions?

In fact, even if a typical landslide user does not want to produce a course material, I think that it is annoying to put ---- between each slide... But maybe it breaks a fundamental assumption of landslide which is that the user is in charge to decide where are the breaks :)

Use of a separator allows to manage slide separation and the amount of information you want or can display on each one… This definitely makes sense in a presentation context, while I guess we could introduce an alternative, less semantically obstrusive separator syntax like say `.. slide` in ReST or `![slide]` in Markdown.

What do others think?

I'm very tempted to get rid of ReST support reading all the "features" it supports. Will be a bunch of painful work to adapt them all to landslide.

Thoughts? Volunteers? Opinions?

My opinion: use rst directives to output precisely the html we want instead of tweaking the current docutils html mode with regex... rst is way more powerful and customizable than markdown, so it would be a pity not to support it... :-/
Sounds good. Well, who?

I modify slide.js and solved it.

```
        case 37: // left arrow
        case 33: // page up
            event.preventDefault();// <= add
            prevSlide();
            break;
        case 39: // right arrow
        case 32: // space
        case 34: // page down
            event.preventDefault();// <= add
            nextSlide();

Thanks for the feedback. Let me see if I can explain the issue better...

If the image isn't found in the following, then `encoded_url` is `False`:

`encoded_url = utils.encode_image_from_url(img_url, source)`

Using `False` for `encoded_url` in the following raised an Exception (expecting unicode but got bool) and the rendering failed:

`html = html.replace(img_url, encoded_url, 1)`

So the issue was in dealing with the situation where the theme image could not be found. This was only happening if using a custom theme. The code was looking in the `THEMES_DIR` instead of looking in the user-specified theme directory:

`source = os.path.join(THEMES_DIR, self.theme, 'css')`

With a custom theme, `source` would point to a non-existing directory and an invalid image file path would be passed to the encoding operation (THEMES_DIR was hard-coded so a custom theme directory would never work).

So you should be able to reproduce the issue by copying tango to a user directory and using -i:

`src/landslide/main.py -i -t ~/my_tango_copy samples/example1`

We often want to obtain a simulated result using a model system of interest.

As far as I can tell, remote files (those starting with "http") are not
retrieved, so they cannot be correctly embedded nor the link is inserted.
My commit is a kind of workaround, but, in some cases, it could also be the
"correct" solution. For example, consider the use case where we need a
"multi-file" remote JS library (like MathJax, as in my real case):
retrieving only the main file would not be the right solution, but managing
the dependencies would be too much hard...

It's not a feature of markdown itself, it's a feature of the python markdown library; `pydoc markdown.extensions` gives (for me, on ubuntu precise)

```
abbr
attr_list
codehilite
def_list
extra
fenced_code
footnotes
headerid
html_tidy
meta
nl2br
rss
smart_strong
tables
toc
wikilinks
```

Note that passing `-x rss` horribly mangles your output, since it drops some rss in the middle of the html :-) Looks like there's provision for writing new ones just by having `mdx_`name`.py` in your `PYTHONPATH`, but I haven't tried that.

(oh, indirectly via issue #42 http://pythonhosted.org/Markdown/extensions/index.html has pointers to documentation for each of them.  A good example might be "Pass `-x toc` and put `[TOC]` on a slide by itself to get a table of contents" (except that it's not smart enough to split slides or anything...)

I have updated this fix to include stopping animated GIFs from playing until the parent slide is active. This required use of the ![Gifffer](https://github.com/krasimir/gifffer) library. There are a couple gotchas with this update:

All images whose src ends with .gif, or base64 images whose "alt" attribute ends with .gif will be changed by the Gifffer function into a button and a canvas element. This may be confusing for someone making a .css file trying to get GIFs positioned a certain way, but not seeing results (because they've been converted to a different tagname). It may be necessary to edit the default .css file and add a comment to clear this confusion.
